div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette An English Daily Newspaper, Established In 1880, Editor and Manager: R. Snelling Price: One Piastre Tariff
div.p: THURSDAY, MARCH 23, 1905.

In the House of Commons yesterday, Lord Selborne referred to the great changes in the naval position of the world ; Russia had be- come a naval power, France maintained her building and efficiency, America and Ger- many had evolved navies of equal strength and efficiency; Italy stood still. England, he said, merely recognised facts. In at- tempting a comparison between Great Britain's naval power and that of other nations, however, there is much to be borne in mind besides numerical strength. Of course, in any comparison the number of ships is the chief consideration—their fighting power and fitness or otherwise to operate against the enemy,their age, size, armament, speed, and general equip- ment for service ; but other questions enter into the range of discussion. There is the personnel of the fleet, the organisation and intelligence of the service, and the power of adaptability to circumstances to get the most oat of whatever ships they may happen to possess. Past history teaches on that the vie' tory has not always been with the greatest number of ships, but has been determined largely by the personal element, the genius of the captain, and the worth of his crew. We live, however, in a different age, and history is no longer a safe guide, although the human element will still count for something in the day of battle. Then there is the work the fleet has to do, the geographical position of the nations con- cerned, the seaboard to be protected, and the extent to which a country is dependent for its life upon its control of the sea. The last-named point appeals particularly to Great Britain in view of her insular position, her great popula- tion, and her almost entire dependence upon foreign grain for very life. Napoleon used to say that armies moved upon their bellies. Everybody does so, and a starving civilian population would end a war quicker even than armed legions or fighting ships. Starvation has ever been a strong weapon of warfare, and it is well for Great Britain, therefore, to bear in mind that in wheat she grows only a fifth of what her people eat. Moreover, it is not only food which must reach Great Britain's shores. Raw material must enter her ports, first, to provide work for her people so that they may have the wherewithal to purchase bread; and, second; to keep her works going, say, in manu- facturing steel in its varied forms for the build- ing or repair of ships and engines to carry on the struggle. If Great Britain's supplies of iron ore, for example, were stopped for a mouth her . steel industry would be at a standstill. Another consideration is the possession of colonies—their extent and liability to attack; their loyalty, and the power they would, or could, exert to defend themselves against the enemy of the mother country. In this respect Great Britain has greater responsibilities than other nations, first, because she owns the greatest colonies; and, secondly, because they are either surrounded by water or their sea- board is extensive. Then there might be noted the naval stations possessed by the various countries—geographical positions strongly held, which tend to strengthen the nation possessing them, while weakening the attacking force. Gibraltar may be take as a case in point—a position which should be worth a good many ships to Great Britain, just as the Kaiser Wil- helm Canal is of great value to Germany, enabling that nation to assemble its fleet in either the North or Baltic Sea without going round by Denmark, thus avoiding the risk of an attack in the Shager Rack and Cattegat

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: Our youthful Cairo contemporary calls us to task for our article on the subject of the Assouan Dam. Nothing pleases the youthful and blows him out with self-conceit so joyously as criticising his seniors. Then, too, it looks like penetrating acumen to discover the identity of a writer, but in this case it is surmise pure and simple, and wrong. As for our "pernicious and unwarranted statement,'' and our bringing in question the good faith of the British Occupation, and that, according to our contemporary, not for the first time, it may enlighten our critic to learn that reclamation of land by British capital is the quickest and most certain means of enabling peasant proprietors to acquire small holdings. Land is so sub- divided and so extremely dear in the old settled parts of the Delta, that it is only by opening up tho waste lands of the lacustrine region that the rising generation can find new homes, and become owners of them. We would recommend the reading of Mr. Hogarth's recant paper on the Nile fen lands in proof of this. The young journalist should remember that whilst knowledge of a subject may place bounds to imagination, it will be found very useful adjunct, if be throws down the gauge to a journal focus turned to weigh well its words, and one of seasoned experience.

div.head: THE WAR. JAPS CONCENTRATING AT TIELING ORDERLY RUSSIAN RETREAT.

div.p: Reuters's correspondent learns from Gun- tzuling, situated 106 miles to the north of Tieling, that, after four days rest at Tieling, the Russians continued their retreat in a uio-t orderly manner, the pursuit being feeble. Oyama is evidently concentrating his army at Tieling where an enormous camp is now being formed. General Kuropatkin returned on the 21st from Kharbin. lie received an ovation. In addressing his troops, he said he hoped that the army would soon retrieve the reverses. ( Reuter.) Tokio, March 22. It is reported that the Russian rearguard was still 20 miles to the north of Kai-Yuen yesterday. The retreat continues along the main routes in the direction of Kirin and Chang Chun. (Reuter.) St. Peterburg, March 22. General Linicvitch signals the appearance of tho enemy at Mackantau. (Havas.)
Tin Tsar has appointed Kuropatkin to the command of the First Manchurian Army. (R.)

div.head: THIRD BALTIC FLEET. EN ROUTE TO PORT SAID.

div.p: Admiral NibogatofFs third Baltic squadron has left for Port Said. (Reuter)

A bomb was thrown to-day from a window of a house here into a patrol of police and infantry : six soldiers and two policemen were dangerously wounded ; the perpetrator escaped. (Reuter.) St. Petersburg, March 22. The disturbances continue in the provinces. A bomb thrown on a patrol at Warsaw wounded 8 soldiers. (Reuter.) St. Petersburg, March 22. The troops proceeding in the districts are most affected by tho rising of tho peasants. The land owners are taking refuge in the towns. ( Reuter.)
A Russian Consulate at Bandarabbas has been established (Reuter.)
A Siamese loan of a million at 4^% will be issued immediately at 954, half in Paris and half in London. It is already quoted at a premium of 13. (Reuter.)
The Queen has arrived here. (Reuter) Lisbon, March 2 Queen Alexandra has arrived. The people: gave her a warm welcome. (Havas)
Emperor William will visit the port of Tangier during his cruise in the Mediterranean. (Havas.)
The budget will be introduced about the 10th of April. (Reuter)

div.head: THE JAPANESE ALLIANCE. STRIKING ARTICLE IN THE "TIMES"

div.p: A striking article appears in the "'Times," based on a letter from its Tokio correspondent dated 10th February, in which the Japanese views on the alliance are enunciated. It declares that there is no danger of any vacilla- tion or weakness on the part of Britain about excluding the interference ol third parties at the final settlement. It proceeds to discuss sympathetically the suggestion of Japanese publicists to transform tho alliance into an agreement absolutely binding on each to assist tho other in the event of war ; the co operation of tho British navy and Japanese army where- ever required to reduce any menace to China, Persia, or Afghanistan into perpetual impotence. The "Times" says it cannot yet determine whether this is within the range of practical politics, but it is confident that if it is realizable it will achieve the great end aimed at (R.)

div.head: THE NAVIES OF THE WORLD. THE "THREE-POWER STANDARD."

div.p: House of Lords. —Lord Guschen justified the vast increase in naval expenditure during the last 15 years by the changes which had taken place throughout the world. He did not think that the loss of 5 Russian battleships justified the decrease made in the British programme. Lord Sel borne referred to the great changes" in the naval position ol the world : Russia had become a naval power, France maintained her building and efficiency; America and Germany had evolved navies of equal strength and Italy stood still. England merely recognized facts. He did not advocate the "three power standard" because he thought that England was unable to afford it. Stability of finances are as necessary as an efficient navy. We must balance one against the other. (Reuter.)

div.head: Domino Dance.—
div.p: There will be a domino dance at the Savoy Hotel on Tuesday next, by special request.

div.head: Suicide.—
div.p: A Russian, aged 50, committed suicide yesterday by throwing himself into the Mahinoudiek Canan, near Moharrcm Bey.

div.head: Suez Canal.—
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst.,of which 4 were British, 2 German, 2 Dutch, 1 Italian, 1 Austrian. The day's receipts were fra 2(H),929.27, making the total from the 1st inst fa. 7,001,369.71.

The Russian Officers who arrived at Port Said on Monday by the "Mongolia," left yes- terday by the S.S. "Lazareff." They have been billeted at the Continental Hotel, as the steamer for Odessa via Alexandria was unable to take them. H.M.S. "Prometheus," third-class cruiser (Commander Woolcombe), arrived at Port Said yesterday morning outward bound for the Australian station, where she will relieve H.M.S. "Pylades."

div.head: The Royal Visit.—
div.p: Last week's "Graphic" contains a number of sketches illustrative of incidents during the recent Royal visit to His pt, also an excellent photographic group of he Royal party, with H.H. the Khedive in the centre, taken at Cairo.

div.head: Cairo Horticultural Show.—
div.p: We should like to urge visitors and residents to do their best to visit the Horticultural Show to be held at Ghezirek next Saturday. The exhibits are expected to reach a high standard of excel- lence and to be more numerous than on most previous occasions.

div.head: Victoria College. —
div.p: Yesterday morning the Duke of Devonshire, accompanied by Mr. E. B. Gould, I.S.O., H. B. M.'s Consul-General, visited Victoria College, where he was received, by Mr. G. B. Alderson, Mr. Kingham, and Mr. Preston, representing the executive com mittee. The Duke, after watching the boys at drill, passed on to the class-rooms, in one of which he spoke to the boys (who had been learning English) of his experiences in the House of Commons and the House of Lords resjieciively, as a member of tho Administra- tions of Lord Palmerston, Mr. Gladstone, the Marquess of Salisbury, and Mr. Balfour. He then inspected the dormitories and soon after- wards left the school amid hearty cheers. The same afternoon the boys enjoyed a half-holiday given at the request of tho Duke, whose visit! gave great pleasure to everyone.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Col. C. J. Markham and officers of the King's Royal Rifles, the band will play the following programme on the Terrace to Gbezireh Palace to-morrow after- noon from 4 to 6 o'clock:— March—Preciosa -Devery. Ouverture—Mirella—Gounod. Selection—Traviata—Verdi. Valse lento—Midsummer—Marigold. The Turkish Patrol—Michcelis. Fantasia—Lohengrin—Wagner. Valse—Blue Bells—Waldtenfel. Gnmd Selection —Erin—Basquit. American Two Step-Mumblin' Moss-Thurban. Regimental March. Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King. TOMAS BROWN, Bandmastor.

div.head: ABYSSINIAN STATE BANK. NATIONAL BANK'S AGREEMENT.
div.p: With regard to the establishment of a State bank in Abyssinia, we understand that the agreement come to between the National Bank of Egypt and the Emperor Menelik comprises:—(1) the monopoly of banking busi- ness for 50 years; (2) the monopoly of minting bank-notes, and (3) the monopoly of entrepots. The capital is to be found by the National Bank of Egypt as to one-half, and by Italian and French financiers as to one-fourth each. Referring to the establishment of the bank, the "Financial Times" says: The Egyptian bank which is interesting itself in this matter is the National Bank of Egypt, and its associa- tion in this enterprise is quite understandable in view of the close relationship between it and the Egyptian Government The institution to be formed will be a small one, and, as a consequence of the commercial condition of Abyssinia, must take the character very much ot a trading institution rather than a bank pure and simple. Its objects are semi-political, and it is unlikely that it will assume any financial importance for some time to come.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held this morning at Aberden Palace under the presidency ol H. H. the Khedive.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: After the Council Ministers this morning, the Khedive held an investiture of the new Sheikh of Al Azhar University. His Highness then gave audience to Saltan Mohamed Effundi, professor of the Dar el Olum school, who thanked his Highness for his appointment as president of the deputation charged to represent the Egyptian Government at the Congress of Orientalists shortly to be held at Algiers. Tho Khedive afterwards gave audience to Prince Mobamed Daoud, Sir Colin Scott- Moncrieff, and Baron Thewotte, military attache to the German Agency. This afternoon his Highness will give audience to Mickalla Pasha, Mouheb Bey, and Zohri Pasha. His Highness will visit the Al Azhar Mosqoe tomorrow for prayers. On Monday the Khedive gave audience to Col. Fitz George and Prince Said Halim.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Suez are now merely submitted to a medical examination, with the excopiion of pilgrims, who. still undergo the usual quarantine restrictions.

div.head: FIRE ON MESSAGERIES STEAMER
div.p: The Messageries mail steamer "Niger," which arrived at Marseilles this day week from Beyrout and Alexandria, reports that shortly after leaving this port fire was discovered in the bold. A panic ensued among the passen- ger, hut calm was ultimately restored and the fire got order alter some hours' work. The passengers wrote a letter of congratulation to the captain of the "Niger" on the measures taken and on the great bravery shown by the crew.

div.head: "LA TOSCA."
div.p: The Khedivial Opera House company select- ed La Tosco as the farewell item on their programme—a wise choice, as it is by far the most agreeable and representative present- ment in their repertoire. La Tosca has already been reviewed in these columns, so we need not re emphasize details. We may say that Signor Girand was better on Friday night than he has been even in previous per- formances of this same opera. Signora Pandol- fini i was as charming as usual, and Signor Polce again showed what a finished actor he is. II Sagrestauo (Signor Galletti) even added to his usual business: his methods in re "la prise religieu8e" of snuff were wholly convincing. Signor Zuccani made the most of that most satisfactory and consistent Leit-motif which pervades this masterpiece of Maestro Puccini from start to finish. He and the composer are alike happy in that this delightful opera has, and entails, none of the confusing variety and gradation which so prominently characterises Ruch writers as Boito, Ponchielli, and Giordano. La Tosca, we may venture to say, was not eminently suited to all the executants, but had its unfailing and direct appeal to the audience; and the consequent success and applause were thoroughly deserved. With this we bid farewell to the company, with every wish for their future success in all their prospective ventures.

div.head: MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.
div.p: Wo publish to-day the programme of a Gymkhana to be held at Mena House to- morrow at 3 p.m. It consists of seven donkey races, three half-mile pony races for gentlemen, and one for ladies. The entrance to the grand- stand is only P.T. 10 for gentlemen and P.T. 5 for ladies. The band of the Inniskilling Fusiliers will play during the afternoon. The management of Mena House Hotel have arranged to have donkeys on hire on . the coarse, which is an improvement on the last Gymkhana. The course is in good order.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The past week has been fall of interest in financial circles. The completeness of the Japanese victory is such, that we begin to "see daylight" The position has been ably described by Lord Rothschild, through the columns of the new "Evening Standard and St James's Gazette." France has to all intents stopped the war by refusing further sinews for the prosecution of it A feature in the situation is that the best- informed are the most confident; and while second-class shares have been full and feature- less, first-class investments still find ready buyers; and though the market has a tired week-end feeling for the moment, and Consols have dropped to 91-5/16, there is every appearance of continued activity. The heaviest and most active settlement which has been seen on the Stock Exchange for years has gone through satisfactorily this week, and business can really be said to be on a sound basis at last, after a long period of stagnation which markets have gone through. There has been a slight check in prices in the Foreign market, where the suspension of negotiations for the new Russian loan made dealers in Paris stocks somewhat cautious. As a matter of fact, this mast in reality be a ball- point, tending as it naturally should do towards the conclusion of peace. Japanese Stocks keep steady on the whole, though not quite main- taining the level of their best prices. Russians are still supported up to 88. In the Consol market money is not quite so easy, and the price has steadied down to 9l£. In Egyptians the feature has been the burst of activity in the mining section, which has really cut itself adrift from Kaffirs this week, and been a little boom of its own. Nile Valleys have .been up to2 j bid; Egyptian Mines have touched 20s. 6d , and Egypt and Sudan Syndicate, to the value of which we have already drawn attention, are firm at 2. Prices have eased off slightly to-day on profit-taking. It is rumored that Egyptian Mines are to be listed on the Paris Bourse, and it is worth noting that, to be able to do this, the price must stand at a minimum of 25s. They close to-night 19s. 6d. Other Egyptian Stocks are steady on the whole, bat not so active. National Banks stand at 27 ; Agri- cultural are easier at 11, after 11. Darias have also given way slightly to 25§, a drop of nearly J. Sugar, Salt and Soda, and Egyptian Markets are unchanged. The new Egyptian Estates have recovered again to a premium.

div.head: THE UM RUS GOLD MINES.
div.p: Mr. Oy J. Alford reports as follows:—"I have just returned from the Um Rus mine, where, on Monday, March the 6th, I had the great pleasure of seeing the first 10 stamps of the mill commence crashing ore, the practical resumption of gold production in Egypt after an interval of several thousand years. When I left the mine the mill was running well, the plates were in excellent condition and amalgam was forming on them in a most satisfactory manner. A clean up will take place about the end of the month, when results will be known. At first and for some little time, until the foundations have had time to consolidate and everything falls into perfect working order, the mill cannot be ran to its full capa- city, which,when attained, will be the crushing by these 10 stamps of about forty tons of ore per twenty-tour hours. The mill is planned for thirty stamps and the remaining batteries, with cyan id ing plant, will bo added when found necessary. The electrical hoisting, stone break- ing, and air-compressing plant at the mine is almost completed, the generating station at the harbour with connections to the mine entirely so, and the whole will be, leaning by the end of the present month. Ore stripping ban been commenced in the 245 ft. level and there is sufficient ore available to keep the mill fully employed for at least six months; meanwhile development work will proceed rapidly as soon as the machine drills get to work. Generally I am well satisfied with the condition add pros- pects of the mine and look with confidence to its future." —

div.head: AT GHEZIREH.
div.p: Gbezireh Palace is still quite fall, and, will be so till the .end of the month. .The thursday dances are always a success. The, next one especially promises to be very successful. The officers of the King's Royal Rifles are giving a dinner party that evening. The band of the regiment will play during the dinner, am afterwards for the dance. Tea parties at Gbezireh have become quite the fashion during the recent spot of warm weather, and we notice among the regular visitors the ex-Empress Eugenie, Sir Ernest Cassel, the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Lady Mary Leith, Mr. Vincent Corbet, Birch Pasha, Slatin Pasha, Sir W. Garetin, .Mr. Waldorf Aster, and many more. The latest arrivals at Ghezireh are H- H. Prince Leopold of Battenherg, H.H. the Maha- rajah of Kapnrthala and suite, Sir William and Lady Crnndell, Major and Lady Mary Leith.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Salaxie" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yester- day morning.

div.head: MARRED BY THE WEATHER
div.p: The bad lack in the matter of weather which has followed the K. S. C. throughout the present racing season attended the olub till the end. Yesterday's meeting was marred by a cold gale, accompanied -by dost and .threats of rain, and the pleasure of the onlookers.was considerably reduced thereby. This was the more deplorable since there were no more than seven races on the programme, which promised, and indeed gave, some ineresting finishes, but the attendance—an important consideration to every club—was greatly diminished by the unseasonable cold. Among those present were Lord and Lady Cromer, Lady Beatrice Thynne, .the Sirdar, Sir .William Garetin, Sir .William and Lady Wiiloooks, Sir El win and Lady Palmer, Sir Ernest Cassel, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, Mr. A. H Webb, M. Leoomte, Mrand Mrs. Brunyate, Mrs. Graham, Coles Pasha, Mr. Riunbold, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. 'Higgins, Col. Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Astley Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Col. Aylmer, Major Herbert, Mrs. and Miss Royle, Miss feel, Mr. Carter .Wilson, Mrs. Ward Boys, Mr. Boys, Mr. Potts, Mr. J). Morice, and many others. In the races, Fadgham did well, winning two events pretty easily, while a. dead heat for 2nd.place in the 1st race between Mahmoud and Timsah deserves notice. Fitz could only get second in the Amateur Stakes, hot be was carrying nearly 3 stone mom than the winner. In the Pinal Plate, The Bard won an unexpected and very admirable victory and rewarded his few hackers most handsomely. The winners as,a role paid well, though place betting .was not a very profitable specu- lation.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke of Devonshire paid a visit, to the Alexandria. Custom House yesterday in company with Chitty Bey, Khalil Bey. Hamdy and other officials of the Administration. Sir Ernest Cassel and the Duke of Devon- shire left Cairo by the 10.90 am. train to-day for Galioub to inspeot the eye-hospital which, as our readers are aware,-is the fruit of Sir Bernest Cassel's generous gift of £50,000. Lord and Lady .Armstrong entertained a party to dinner yesterday evening at the Savoy Restaurant, the guests including Bogbos Pasha Nubar, Col. Sir Augustus FilzGeorge, Hiss FitzGeorge, Major and Mrs. Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. Perkins, Col and Mrs. J.K. Watson, and Col. Friend. The ex-Empress Eugenie bad at her table Major-General Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha, Comte Clary, Princesse Bonaparte de la Moskowa, Comte Primoli, and Mue deBassano. H. R the Governor returned from Cairo yesterday evening Comte Tyskiewicz, who has been up .the Nile as far as Gondokoro, is doe,book at Shepheard's on Sunday next Baroness von Adelsheim and her daughter, who Vhave been spending several weeks at Assouan, are returning to Shepheard's early in April. Mr. C. J. Alford, the eminent mining engineer, is at present in Alexandria and leaves for Europe on Saturday by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. Mr. Raoul Wilkinson has contributed £1 to the funds of the Arifo Rudolph in Memory of the late George Sooolis,

div.head: THE NEW SECONDARY SCHOOL (From a Correspondent).
div.p: The need has long been felt for another secondary school in Egypt. Three already exist, viz, the Tewfikieh and Khedivieh in Cairo and Ras el-Tin in Alexandria. But they have proved incapable of holding the vast number of students, which goes on increasing every year, and it is for this reason that the Ministry of Public Instruction lately decided on the foundation of a fourth. It seems that the question as to the place where it was to be established has received a good deal of attention. The Ministry had two points to take into consideration, viz., the comfort of the students and that of the masters. As far as Egyptian opinion can be ascertain- ed, the need of the country requires that the school should be somewhere within the reach of those who have at present to travel some twenty or even more hours to get to Cairo. Among the students of the Tewfikieh and Khedivieh Schools there is a large number from the far southern parts of Upper Egypt, such as Girgeh, Ketieh, and Assouan. It means money and time for these students to travel a long distance between their native towns and the Capital. In considering these difficulties we must bear in mind that not a small number of these students have not the means to meet the expenses of a Cairo life, added to the cost of travel, and accordingly they have to remain where they are, simply because they cannot be within reach of a secondary school in Upper Egypt near their homes. Assiout is the right place for such a school. Ras-el-Tin School at Alexandria satisfies the needs to the Behera and Gharbieh provinces. The Cairo schools meet the requirements of the remaining provinces of Lower Egypt and the northern part of Upper Egypt up to Beni Souef. There remains thus the greater part or Upper Egypt,from Minieh in the north to Haifa in the south, with its dense population of about three millions in need of a secondary school. Assiout lies in the centre of this region, or nearly so; and no less than two or three hun- dred students now these provinces find them- selves at present within the doors to the Tewfikieh and Khedivieh schools. But there remains a second point to be taken into consideration. This new school naturally needs English masters, who would feel lonely in Upper Egypt. They consider it a curse to be away from the Turf Club, the Ghezireh grounds, the Khedivial bails, the Opera House, and the like. It is certainly much more convenient for them to live in Cairo than in Assiout; and this is the second point the Ministry of Public Instruction had to take into consideration. These two points have to be placed in the scales, and whichever draws the balance has to ba the reason for deciding the place where the school is to be built. It seems that the Minis- try has already performed the operation, as I see in some papers that it has been decided that Ghizeh is to be the site for the new school. If this is true, and I hope it is not, the Ministry has made a giant mistake. The needs of the country and the comfort of four or five hundred students, together with their families, should certainly outweigh the comfort of five or six English masters. A new school at Gbizeh would simply mean the enlargement of the Cairo schools, without adding to their number of pupils. Life in Upper Egypt is not, after all, so tiring?. Inspectors of Pittance and the Interior, Irrigation officers, and bank agents live easily in the provinces. The Sudan is not more com- fortable than Upper Egypt is ; and it is to be remarked that tho school is meant for the students and not for the masters, an . that th > Ministry can easily change its decision if it has already formed one.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR. We do not hold ourselves responsible for opinions expressed by our correspondents. But we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permits, within certain necessary limits - free discussion.
EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,— The statement in yesterday's "Gazette," that owing to the indebtedness of the Egyptian Cotton Mills to the Government, to the extent of £3,000 to £4,000 for taxes, which the company is unable to pay, the mills are to be closed, will be very serious reading to a large number of investors in this country. Your correspondent, "An Old Shareholder," suggests that to save the industry being strangled by the countervailing duty, Lord Cromer should be approached, but in this case 1 have no doubt that Lord Cromer's hands are tied, and that the only interests concerned are the Lancashire constituencies, which, in view of the approaching General Election, the Go- vernment cannot afford to disregard. Last year, we were treated to pathetic stories of the wrongs done to Lancashire by the wicked operations of Mr. Sully, and of the poor, starv- ing mill hands, who were sacrificed as victims to the Yankee cotton speculators. But Lan- cashire does not consider anything when its own interests are concerned, and to please the powerful interests of that county, a promising Egyptian industry is to be crushed out of existence. The time will come very soon, far sooner than we reck of, when the pressure on the soil will become a very serious question, and the fellah will no longer concentrate all his energies on agriculture. Population in- creases with extraordinary rapidity and land is limited. Industrial development will be one of the great, perhaps the grotest, feature of Egyptian progress in the immediate future, and one of the natural industries of the country should be spinning and weaving. Your correspondent expresses a hope that Lord Cromer will be appealed to aim will hearken to the prayers of this industry, which is doomed to die still-born. But Lord Cromer has a double duty. He has not only the interests of Egypt to look after, but he is also the representative of the British Government, and must take his orders from that Govern- ment We all know that he is left entirely to his own discretion in regard to internal matters, and that the authorities resolutely refuse to listen to the cracks and faddists who attempt to introduce their pet schemes into Egypt The answers to the questions on Egypt in the House of Commons show the implicit confi- dence which the Government has in Lord Cromer. But when it comas to external matters, influences from home are brought to bear, and the perfunctory defense which his lordship makes of the case against the Cotton Mills in the 1901 Keport clearly shows that he did not act of his own free will in the matter. If it was a valid argument that this industry should be shackled, because, if developed, it would imperil the revenue derived from the Customs duties on cotton goods, the same line of reasoning should be applied to the breweries, soap-manufactories, and all the other industries, which are competing with the revenue derived from imports into Egypt. But while new industries are springing up, the products of which decrease tho need for similar exports, they are never shackled by a countervailing excise. There is no need to elaborate the argument. It is hardly necessary for me to write this letter, for the industry is doomed to be crushed out in the interests of Lancashire and no power can save it But the episode will always remain a blot on the history of England in Egypt and, as far as I ran see, I am glad to say the episode is the only case of political immorality of which our country has been guilty in her relations with Egypt. I am not, I may add, a shareholder in the concern, but "A Mere Observer." Cairo, March 92.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE:
div.p: Sir,—One would have thought when two great engineers held different views about the Assouan Dam, that the one who opened the attack would have cited some more recent authority on engineering than the writer of Boclesiastes. The wresting of the words "Afraid of that which is high" to make them apply to a masonry dam, and at the same time prove decrepitude on the part of an adversary, and discredit his opinion officially expressed, is a perfect gem of naive misuse of Scripture. It is : something to live up to one's motto, even if it: is "L'andaoe, toujours randaco." Job XII. 33. tells ns "Upon earth there is not his like, "who is made without fear. What food I ate lay like a load on my chest. I could not digest it at alL I had such in- digestion that 1 was loath to eat the simplest food. "My exhausted and bloodless state I had heard described as Anjcmia. Many of the girls with whom I work had the same complaint, and they told me Dr. Williams' Pink Pills would cure when nothing else could. They wrought wonders. I only round it necessary to purchase a single box. To my relief and joy I felt Well and Strong After These Few Pills. Anaemia vanished, and a tinge of colour quickly came into my face. div.head: THE DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY LIMITED NOTICE TO SHAREHOLDERS.
div.p: In accordance with the terms of the. Addi- tional Article of teo 4th June 1904 to the Agreement of the 18th November 1902, enter- ed into between the Comptrollers of the Daira Saniah, acting under the authority of their respective Governments, and the Daira Sanieh Company Limited, the Directors now propose to constitute a Company under Egyptian Law which is to take over the assets and liabilities of this Company. A draft Agreement for this purpose will be submitted for consideration at the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Shareholders to be held on the 27 the inst. On the same day, separate meetings of the holders of Ordinary and of Deferred Shares will be held in accordance with Article 25 of the Articles of Association. S. De Bilinski, Secretary. Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, 4th March 1905.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Ex- traordinary General Meeting of the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited, will be held at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, on Monday the 27th day of March 1905 at 3 o'clock in the afternoon for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolution. RESOLUTION. That the Board be authorized to enter into an Agreement with a Company about to be formed under .Egyptian Law with the title of "La Socidtd Egyptienue de la Daira Sanieh" or some similar title, or with a Trustee for such Company, in the terms of a draft which will be submitted to the Meeting, subject to such modifications as the Board may think fit, for the sale to such company of the whole of the undertak- ing, business and assets of the Company, subject to its liabilities, and that this Meeting hereby sanctions the scheme of distribution of the proceeds of sale therein provided for. Dated this fourth day of March 1905. By Order of the Board. S. de Biunski, Secretary. Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo. A draft of the Agreement can be seen in Cairo at the Offices of the Company, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, and at the Office of Malt re Carton de Wiart, Legal Adviser to the Com- pany, at any time daring business hours during the ten days immediately preceding the Meet- ing, and in London at the Offices of Messrs. Norton, Rose, Norton, Farish and Co., the Solicitors for the Company, 575 Old Broad Street, E.C., at any time during business hours during the fifteen days immediately preceding the Meeting. Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer, who wish to attend the above Meeting, must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, to- gether with a statement of their names and addresses, either with the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo or Alexandria, two clear days before the date of the Meeting (viz., not later than 24th March), or with the National Bank of Egypt in London, 4 and 5, King William Street, E.C., ten clear days before the date of the Meeting (viz., not later than 15th March), the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the Meeting shall have been held. Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, and a ticket of admission (which must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and Forms of Proxy. If the Depositor does not intend personally to attend the Meeting, a Proxy in favor of the person producing the Certificate must be lodged with the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo or Alexandria not less than forty-eight hours before the Meeting. NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that a meet- ing of the Ordinary Shareholders of the Daira Sanieh Company Limited will be held at the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo on Monday the 27th day of March 1905 at 3.30 o'clock in the afternoon or so soon thereafter as the Ex- traordinary General Meeting convened for 3 o clock may have terminated, for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolution. RESOLUTION.
